Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Wings to Flippers-Phylogenetics, Character Acquisition, and Feather Biomechanics in the Evolution of Wing-Propelled Diving
Award.AbstractNarration:
While transformations to an aquatic lifestyle have been intensely studied in organisms ranging from insects to whales, basic questions remain unanswered for birds: e.g., how many times has 'aquatic flight' been gained and aerial flight lost? A large collaborative team will focus on resolving the controversial evolutionary relationships of wing-propelled diving birds (including new fossils). Phylogenetic comparative methods will be used to investigate musculoskeletal, neurosensory, and feather microstructure changes across aerial to aquatic flight transitions. Techniques such as X-ray computed tomography, histology, and computer modeling will also be utilized.

Broader impacts focus on interdisciplinary undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral training in systematics, histology and biomechanics. Highlights include a mentored research experience for undergraduate students from under-represented groups. Public outreach and education activities include co-instruction of a 3 year Geoscience module of the nationally-recognized UTeach secondary school teacher preparation program, Expanding Your Horizons workshops to encourage young women to pursue science careers, web-cast lectures and distribution of curricular materials via university and museum programs, and a dedicated blog. Broad dissemination of research findings is achieved through peer-reviewed publications, conference presentations, and data sharing via online databases.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit Outcomes: We tracked shifts in many major character systems to understand their evolution across the transition to avian underwater flight, which involves cooption of the flight stroke used in aerial flight for underwater diving. Our discovery and description of the first fossil penguin with feathers has major implications for the evolution of feather morphology and color in penguins. We discovered that penguin feather morphology evolved early in their evolution before major skeletal changes (a pattern also seen in the origin of avian flight). We also report for the first time that early penguin coloration appears to be distinct from living penguins. Living penguins we exhibit several novel modes of coloring their feathers. We reassessed the evolution of character systems including wing proportions, bone histology, wing feathering, feather coloration, eye, inner ear and brain morphology across the target clades. This work, among other findings showed far more plasticity in gross brain morphology in closely-related and recently-divergent taxa than previously thought. These results had important implications for the inference of function/neurosensory traits in extinct taxa from brain morphology. Finally, we published fossil calibrations for the target clades for use in molecular divergence dating by biologists and published a two new metrics for assessing time tree (~molecular estimates for the origins of clades) fit with the fossil record. Our results were disseminated in more than 14 publications and 25 conference presentations.

 

Broader Impacts Outcomes: Our project resulted in extensive student and postdoctoral training opportunities. Three PhD and two masters students received training as part of the project. More than 10 other undergraduates gained research experience. One of these undergraduates completed an honors thesis on the evolution of wing feathering and presented research results at an international meeting. Two postdoctoral scholars were trained.  Other outreach included public talks, media coverage of major findings, curriculum development for K-12 teachers as well as creation of blog on project related research. Finally, we co-organized an international workshop and symposium held in Hokkaido, Japan in 2014 to synthesize findings and chart future directions for research with specialists working on behavioral and functional aspects of this key behavior in living birds.
